Do note that the planetarium is only open on weekends(so we missed it), and that the submarine tour, though interesting, was entirely in Turkish. We did get a leaflet explaining the submarine's main features in English, but as the tour was given in the reverse order to the directions, by the time we sorted things, we'd missed quite a bit. But was a lovely experience overall, and we spent three and a half hours there and were'nt done! If you are automobile, or science buffs, plan to spend a while!

A surprisingly well-designed and enjoyable museum in Istanbul. The Rahmi M. Koc Museum carries the name of its benefactor, the (former) chairman of the board for one of the largest conglomerates in Turkey, the Koc Holdings. It is hard to categorize this museum - it is not really a science museum, it is not a history museum, it is not a transportation museum, it is not a technology museum, it is not a toy museum, but rather it is a bit of everything. Perhaps it is a museum that tells the story of industrialization in Istanbul starting from the latter years of the Ottoman Empire (mid 1880s) to today's modern Turkey. The above description may imply that the museum has a mishmash of items, and that may turn off a potential visitor. It should not! You may think that you have little or no interest in such a museum. You should not!The museum is surprisingly well-designed and enjoyable. Everything is described both in Turkish and English. The museum has a large collection of antique cars, boats, train cars / locomotives and planes as well as a large ferry and a full size submarine. Also included in the museum grounds are an impressive collection of model ships, telecommunications equipment, toys, measurement equipment and standards, all displayed in a series of buildings and courtyards along the Golden Horn.If you are visiting with kids, this is a particularly good choice, as kids will find tons of things to do. In addition to those collections listed above, there are math and science games for kids, as well as a planetarium that shows a variety of shows.If located in any other city, this would have been a five star attraction. Perhaps the only reason why I am giving this a four star is because Istanbul has so many five star attractions that this one just quite does rise to the level of those (such as Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Rustem Pasa Mosque, Suleymaniye Mosque, Chora Museum, Bosporus Tour, Underground Cistern, Topkapi Palace, Istanbul Museum of Archeology, view from Camlica Hill, etc.) But if you have done all of those, and/or you have kids (including teens), you will enjoy this museum. Set aside at least 3 hours to visit. The museum has a nice restaurant and a cafe (inside the refurbished ferry), and the prices are very very reasonable.Finally, while the setting for this museum (along the Golden Horn) is spectacular, getting there is a bit of a challenge. Easiest way: Get to Karakoy (or Eminonu) and then take a taxi. It should only be about 12-15 Liras ($6-8 as of November 2014).
One of the top Istanbul places to go. At the heart of the historic golden horn, pleasant ambience with music, view, seating, service, food quality. Unique.
fabulous. this place has amazing things and i really can not believe it. great helpful people very welcoming, i happy i went when had the chance to

nice hidden museum. this museum is not on the route of public transport of istanbul,but it is not far from them.so it will cost you just 10 to 15 dollars to reach it by taxi depending on where you hire the taxi from beyoglu are or sultan ahmet area.it takes only 15 miuntes to reach it by taxi. we went in the morning and got the main ticket and extra ticket for the submarine.I like all of the exhibits that the museum has to offer. the classic cars and planes are the best along with the submarine.fantastic museum

Gizmos, Gadgets, & Good Stuff. Boy, it must be fun to be filthy rich and to buy all the toys you want. But it must be even more fun to build a groovy museum around all your loot and to share it with the world, as the Koc family has done.

Well worth the visit. Small private museum that is definitely worth your visit. The collection and breadth of it are spectacular. Don't mind the walking, and either have some information or guide to assist you as you go around.

The biggest individual museum in Turkey. The owner of the museum is stil alive and he is one of shareholders of biggest group in Turkey called Koc Holding. Koc Holding first invested to automotive industry in Turkey and most of the parts of museum are related to automotive, machines, mechanics.The location of the museum is perfectly selected. Enjoy with yoru visit.

A good day out. We were expecting a quick look at some old types of transport previously used around Istanbul - how wrong can you be!? We could have easily spent the entire day working our way around the displays of every transport type you would expect and the additional displays of private and personal memorabilia from a very full lifetime. Very much worth a visit if you can spare the time.

İnteresting. Reaching to the Museum is very easy. Area is an historical place .
İnside very peaceful. You can find there what you expect in every sense.
I liked that historical Submarine,it is very interesting.

One of the best I have ever been to. This is a private family museum - do not miss it. The collection is extraordinary, especially the very old ceramics on the fourth floor. Exquisite jewelry - not to be missed. Worth the trip.
fantastic to visit. easy to get around with many exhibits you will not see elsewhere. the layout is well organised with exhibits from dolls houses to full size submarines and tug boats

Get off the bus tour and visit this place. Luckily, I had read about this place before we set off on the hop on hop off bus tour, so we made a point of getting off at this stop. I am not particularly a transport enthusiast but I found the Museum very impressive. There is quite a lot to see and the quality of the exhibits and the presentation is outstanding. It was not at all busy and it was a really lovely way to spend a few hours away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Well worth a visit.

Excellent Museum. If you like any kind of transportation, cars, boats, planes, tractors, wagons, motorcycles, you will we wowed by the collection in this private museum.This a Museum which is a must for all transport enthusiasts. Located in a former shipyard in the Golden Horn near Hasköy area.I can enthusiastically recommend this museum to any visitor. Children will love the 'hands on' elements. And if, unlike me, you are enough of a transport enthusiast to wish to study each exhibit individually, you could be here for a few days!

A submarine, a planetarium, planes, trains, automobiles and more.... This is a fantastic place for all ages to spend a whole day in. There is a submarine tour ( a veteran retired submarine leased from the navy, definitely worth the extra few pounds) as well as a planetarium at extra cost but the rest of the museum is excellent value given the wealth of collections here: classic cars, boats, war planes with human stories behind them, displays of cross-sections of cars, home appliances encased in transparent material for the inner workings to be visible while in operation accompanied by screens displaying child friendly animations in Turkish and English, a very hands-on mathematics section, a small historic toy collection, a world war I battle field ambulance, a model olive oil factory, ancient fire engines, horse and train carriages including replicas of those that belonged to sultans , maritime cranes and equipment, 1 excellent restaurant and 3 little cafes one of which is housed in a disused but renovated passenger ferry boat. At the time of our visit a new gallery was being arranged for model houses exhibition. This visit ended up being a fascinating range of industrial experiences from moving between submarine chambers by squeezing through the hatches between them to viewing the inside of a dishwasher while it is being operated! My little boy was mesmerised by many of the exhibits and loved the hands-on mathematics section where there were about a dozen interactive stations.Regardless of which city in the world this museum is located in, it would be a great shame to leave it out of one’s travel itinerary but in a city renowned for its palaces, hamams, mosques and bazaars, visiting it would add a pleasantly surprising variety to your time. I can not recommend it enough.

Really is a must see. A museum 'dedicated to the history of transportation, industry and communication'. I was surprised that such a dry description was attached to an attraction rated so highly on Trip Advisor's list of things to see and do in Istanbul. Still, I trusted the reviews and went along and was very glad I did, as were the rest of my family, ranging from 6 to 70.While Sultanahmet should, of course, be your first priority in Istanbul, I would put this a strong second. Funded by one of Turkey's wealthiest families this museum has clearly been assembled out of love rather than any drive to make money. There is a truly fantastic, and fascinating, collection of classic cars, ships, trains and planes that have to be seen to be believed. In addition, hands on mathematics section that (even) kids will love and a planetarium (at extra cost). The crowning glory is the opportunity to tour an ex-military, 100 metre submarine (an inexpensive extra), floating in the Golden Horn - something truly unique.I guess I should mention that food and refreshment is available on site and you do not need a good weather day to make the most of this.In summary, I really can't recommend this enough. Definitely deserves 5 stars.

Science education. Agree with other reviews that you find a fascinating collection of diverse objects of transport, industry and communication. It has a Turkish focus such as the Anadolu car experiment and the Turgut Alp Sea Crane! In addition it offers an explicit education component (touch and learn). It would be difficult to walk away without having learned something new! well worth on a rainy day in Istanbul!

Brilliant, you must spend a whole day here. Really a wonderful museum to visit, no queues, very inexpensive and so many fantastic things to see. Cars, planes, trains, boats, a submarine, toys, Turkish life, all very well presented with English and Turkish captions, very interactive, excellent for children. Lots of eating options from delicious restaurant to cafés. Don't underestimate the time you will want to spend here. Mr Koc, the patron and collector of this museum is a genius to have put this together and it is a delight. The site is on the golden horn by the water, lovely views across the city. I want to go back as did not have time to see it all. Excellent all round

do NOT miss this. I have never been to a more amazing 'real-life' museum. Ranges from a floating submarine, fighter jets on pedestals, 200/300 cars of all vintages - including an example of a very early Ford Mustang - all in excellent condition. And lots and lots of different machinery, ranging from fire trucks to internal combustion engines to old ferry boats to a 1939 ship's engine (all 4 stories of it, standing under cover on the quay, having been rescued from a cargo ship that was scrapped some years ago). If you a wife reading this, and you want your husband to be totally distracted for a whole day while you pursue your shopping etc., this is the place. And then there is a seriously good restuarant right on the water where you can meet up at lunch time or in the evening (not cheap, but totally 5 star). This museum was put together by one man with unbridled taste and money, and it shows.

More than planes, trains & automobiles. . Take the Goldern Horn ferry and get off at Haskoy. Make sure you see both sides of the museum. The non-waterside section is housed in an old foundry.When you buy the additional submarine ticket you are given an allocated guided tour time.There is a small cafe inside the museum serving tea/coffee and sandwiches/snacks with seating. Or a more expensive restaurant located on the waters edge.Allocate at least 2-3 hours. HIGHTLIGHTSinclude the flying car from Harry Potter, and Top Gear Top 41 car. A must for children.

Not your actual mosque!. When you've seen the mosques and you're feeling bazaar'd out, do not overlook the Rhami Koch Industrial Museum. This is a gem of a site with a dazzling display of classic cars, toys, an outstanding maritime and aviation museum, an array of railway memorabilia and, to cap it all, a tour round a WW2 submarine. It is reached by a water taxi ride to Haskoy, two stops up the Golden Horn from Eminonu.There is also the exquisite Cafe du Levant on site where even the loos are photo worthy.A great trip for kids of all ages especially on a wet day. Oh, and did I mention the planetarium?Don't miss it.
Transportations Museum. You must put this in the Must-to-Do List. Includes most of transportation machine, vehicles, vessels, planes, ... etc
Very interesting especially for kids. Kids will enjoy it very much and will learn a lot, it mixes fun and education, if you have kids you must visit Rahmi Koç Museum when you visit Istanbul

How the Turkey sees the West. Turkey has always been a pendulum between the East and West. Ataturk, the Father of Turkey, firmly believed its future must be Western creating a secular state. However Turkey is now perceived by many as swinging back to the East. This museum is an attempt by one of Turkey's greatest (and wealthiest) businessman to both give something back to the Turkish people and stem the swing to the East. If you are a Western tourist this museum is worth visiting because it will give you an understanding of how the West was so successful based on technological leadership. It will also give you an understanding of how the West is perceived.

My husband was enthralled. My husband spent hours here, and couldn't get over the quality of the exhibits and the collections. He loved the miniature steam engines, was gushed about the restored Fiat railcar, was amazed at the recovered Hadleys Harem B24 that was shelled during WW II, etc. He kept talking about the car collection, and the dioramas. On and on....We spent extra on touring the submarine with a former crew member who served on the sub with the Turkish Navy. Easy to get to via the Haliç-Hatti Ferry off Eminönü.

could never imagine. I could never imagine I would find a museum like that in Istanbul. But, after some reconsideration, it seems that a boy grew his fascination with auto, air, train, boat models into a full size accomplishment.

Great!. This is a great museum - we went with the kids and the parents, and really enjoyed it. There are lots of different attractions, many to do with transport. e.g.SubmarineDC10 planeGreat number of model railway displaysLots of classic carsCutaway engines from cars, tractors, and a cutaway washing machine, for seeing how they work.Some big engineering items - ships' engines etc....and more.You could spend a half-day here, or a whole day if you wanted to see more of the things there. It's also near Miniaturk.

Top 5 places for kids (and car lovers) in Istanbul. If you or your kids are into planes, trains, or automobiles (or boats), this is place! An amazing collection of classic cars, plus plenty of trains, trolleys, planes that you can board, boats, motorcycles, and a train that you can ride on weekends. Definitely recommend going on a weekend when the train is operating. It's also a beautiful location on the Golden Horn, and there is a playground next door too. The only sad part is that many of the Istanbul locals don't know about this place, so it is usually empty! We've been many times and my 3 year old son can't get enough. You can go for an hour, or spend most of the day if you're interested. It's also not too far from most of the touristy areas. With no traffic, it's a 10 minute taxi from Taksim or 15 from the the Old City. With traffic maybe 30 minutes.

a fantastic afternoon. this is a wonderful museum for all ages, from toys to submarines taking in all sorts of transport it is a quirky but coherent collections. It is laid out extremely well and is exceptionally well maintained it also features cafe's and restaurants for all people and all pockets you do not have to be a transport fanatic to enjoy this, it gives a unique insight into industrial and social historywe had a great afternoontake a taxi to get there and leave before the rush hour

Rahmi M. Koc Museum. It is off the main tourist drag and out of the main part of Beyoglu, overall it is somewhat interesting and has many fascinating accounts and objects on display. But it is an overly large collection. My advice is only go there if you are willing to spend all day looking at a mass collection of vehicles, boats, models, and just various possessions of the museums namesake, who very well could be the man implied in the Dos Equis ads [ the most interesting man in the world ].
Not for everyone, but quite interesting!. I loved the restored cars and displays in this museum! The Koc family sure has some big bucks to own all of this!

Very nice museum... The exhibition is very wide, interesting and impressively modern. A must-see in Istanbul. Unfortunately, its position is hard to reach by foot.. and the public transport is limited. I reached the Rahmi Koc Museum using the Big Bus Tour, blue line.. However, it deserves being visited despite the effort the reach it. I liked very much the fact that the museum is very interactive.. and also the exbition quite mix international history of transport with the Turkish history of transport..

Excellent collection. What a wonderful museum. Just big enough to give a wonderful glimpse of modern history. Every car, train, boat was beautifully restored. This is an outstanding collection of one man's Transportation Fascination. Set in a restored warehouse on the Golden Horn waterway, this is a great place to visit and learn and get a bit outside of busy Istanbul.

a fantastic museum. this is an absolutely fantastic museum, well worth combining with miniaturk as along the same road.a little hard to get to and from,but a real gem when you get there.it covers all aspects from trains, planes and automobiles (a plane to go in) and is very detailed, you need hours here and there is a sub you can tour for a few extra lira which is also well worth it.it`s totally different to everything else in istanbul and well worth the break from mosques etc.there is definitely something for everyone in here.with miniaturk these day take a whole day.there is a boat from kabatas that stops here if you don`t fancy a taxi or many buses, all seem to go back to the centre of istanbul.if here for 5 days well worth one of the days here, should be next on list after mosques, bazaars, cistern, hagia sophia, hareems etc..

Beats anything in the UK. Weve been to quite a few museums and this has got to be the best and it captivated us for a whole 5 hours. Very interactive. All in english and turkish. A fantastic insight of one little boys passion for mechanical things. Love love love the place. Great value for money.

Great place to spend a day.. For a family with kids or toddlers, this is a great place to spend a day or two. Has multiple restaurants, and activities to keep kids busy and entertained. When leaving, we had to promise our daughter to bring her back.

Not FORD museum, but.... It is a very compact and filled with everything. You can find cars, trucks, boats, painting, sculpture and more.Nice, neat museum. Sometimes they have special exhibitions which is really cool.

Best Museum a have ever seen. First time in my life I have spent 3 hours in a museum and it was a quick tour. If you spend all day there you never get bored. There are dozens wonders all around museum, from cuntury old cars to personal belonging of owner, from Real historical train station to cozy restaurants and cafas with magnificant views off city or museum's wonders.
Quirky, eccentric and great. Go by ferry to this attraction using your Istanbul card. A really quirky history of all things mechanical. Not complete and not really in-depth, but nice anyway.

Literally a travel machine!. I call Rahmi M. Koc Museum a time machine traveler! The place steps you back in time and future! Pity we only discovered it towards the end of our trip. After our visit to Istanbul's "must seen sights" we needed to see that "extra" thing...and Rahmi Museum was beyond than a good choice.We were a bit worried whether our young daughter (3 years and half) would be entertained but to my surpise she's still asking for the retro red car and the nostalgic train ride!We reached the place via a taxi (costed us 25TL from Blue Mosque) and returned back via public bus ( using our IstanbulKart). We decided to visit the museum during the harsh hours of day , so wondering around with public transportation on a hot day with a baby trolley was not a goood idea. Thus we picked taxi and chose to return back via bus (which to my surprise was very easy handling it with a baby's trolley!!! Bus stop is excatly outside of the entrance. Last stop of it at Eminonu).Two thumps up to ithe museum managment and personel for the effort to discover and maintain so well soooo many exhibits ! I really enjoyed the section with the trains. Literally last thing I was expecting was me sitting and "feeling" the vintage aura of an italian retro 1st class wagon!! Fenerbache Boat and the submarine tour is a must! While entrance is not allowed for toddlers at the Submarine (kids under 8 years old are not allowed), I really enjoyed the exhibition hosted on the boat of vintage toys. I was thrilled to see some old toys that used to be my fav passtime play! Treat yourself with a hot cupt of tea after ther submarine tour and do take it on the boat's deck even if it's a bit humid and hot. The view of the Golden Horn and the seaguls' sounds will defenitely pay you off!Museum has a vast exhibits. Steam cars, retro firecars, shiny boats, penny farthing type bycicles jump into your eyes all over !!The place is enormous, be prepared to spend half day if you want to see all exhibits. I have to admit that we've skipped a couple of them due to to time pressure! If you understand turkish language do go to the planetarium (unfortunately the videos there, are in turkish).If you feel tired take advantage of the small coffe shops in the museum: treat yourself with a typical glass of tea or coffee either on the Fenerbache Boat, or at the cute and cozy coffee shop at the entrance of the antique automobiles or enjoy lunch outdoors at one of the restuarants of the museum.Highlights of the visit:a) Hasköy – Sütlüce Railway( don't get the idea that you will go around the city with a retro wagon... :) but those 20 minitues ride in a retro wagon will give you the taste of how things worked back in time. So nostalgic!b) spend a few more minutes in the Living History section. Smell the essence of cinamon of the old pharmacy, observe the old guy trying to fix a clock, make or hear the sound of the shoe maker.... c) get on the Douglas DC-3 'Dakota'!!! Seat on the chairs and travel back in time!d) when visting the navigation department, go to the fishing types boats and at the end of the corridor you will come across an exhibit that pictures an old fisherman with a kid (articificial models) fixing their fishing nets while the radio is tuned to nice melodies. This images takes literally there!e) if you into science, definetly visit the collection of scientific devices as well as the section of Science and Technology Workshop. After the visit you 'll definetly know how on earth your home devices work (besides the basic : put the plug on and switch on the outlet! )f) if you have Museum Pass Card Advantage you will benefit %20 discount on the entrance and %10 discount in the shop. The gift shop has really gifts at good prices!Overall: I will definetly return back to catch up to all the exhibits I left behind and to have again my tea on the Fenerbache Ferry's deck! Worthed every single lira we paid for it!

Great place....must visit if u want ur kids to live a different experience. Went there with my 6 and 8 years old kids and had a wonderful time....we spent 5 hours and the kids didn't get enough !!Submarine visit takes u back in history to WWII..must do if u r here

Thank you tripadvisor!. Man, traveling to Turkey with a six-year-old boy in the middle of the summer is not a picnic. I was starting to think that maybe we were crazy for choosing this city...in this 90 + degree heat. But this is the one attraction where TripAdvisor did not lead me astray....we got here later in the afternoon late July and there wasn't a line for tickets, we took our time going through the rooms...and the whole family really loved it. There are trains and boats outside where it's still a little steamy, but there is a cafe to cool off and grab a Coke and it's right on the water. He was a little disappointed that he was too young to go on the submarine, but it was definitely worth the trip!!

A living museum. Well curated museum and while I have no young children, as a museum professional, I was pleased to see the museum children-friendly and encouraging learning activities. Staff helpful and pleasant, refreshments easily available and well priced. Object labelling is clear, accurate and in two languages (Turkish and English). Full marks for working exhibits! The collection scores well on both the breadth and depth of the collection.

Crowded with school kids. Seems like this is an easy place for teachers to take kids on field trips, so it was packed with school groups. All the old cars were interesting -- but they were American and I can see those in museums at home. In fact, a lot of the stuff was American. Not much Turkish.
Superb experience. Great museum! Our 6 year old boy enjoyed as much as we did. Everything is there: from impressive old timer collection to challenging tasks for adults and kids.

My favorit... This is my favorit museum in Istanbul. It is a huge area to visit. You can see the amazing collection of Koc family. It is very interesting for kids and adults as well. Sub marine and plane are my favorit equipments to see. Dont miss

Very interesting. One of the most interesting places you can visit in Istanbul. I loved the classic cars trains and boats. I found the submarine cool. The place is great if you have kids they will enjoy it. It has different parts and in all it is quite a nice hang out .will definitely enjoy going there again.

Loved this museum. This museum has beautiful collection of classic cars, trams, trains. It has a ferryboat, a plane and a submarine. Also, there are some very interesting collections of toys from all times and baby trolleys.

When five stars is just not enough. This is simply an amazing find. We have been to Istanbul six times and we thought we had seen and experienced everything. Well, we were wrong. We went to this museum on the strength of TripAdvisor traveler recommendations. We allowed an hour for this attraction. Four hours into it, our legs gave out and we quit even though there was still much to see. This is probably one of the finest attractions we have ever seen anywhere on anything, a huge collection of perfectly restored old and antique cars, a huge boat and navigational artifacts, a remarkable collection of street cars starting with horse drawn trams, old train cars, the original steam powered cable car up to Galata hill from 1875, an excellent aviation collection, etc. You get the idea, if it moves they have it. All the exhibits are well described and documented in both English an Turkish. Must see to believe how well done this is.For a break you can stop for drinks and snacks at the adjacent Halat cafe/restaurant. A beautiful and elegant setting. We are coming back for dinner at this most incredible spot right on the Bosphorus with the historic Istanbul in the background. Best to take a taxi. Not easily accessible on foot without serious knowledge of public transportation.

Such a cool museum!. Private museum. Had cars, trains, planes, boats...thinking it was just for the boys,,,I was readily dismissing. But boy oh boy, was I surprised!!! I lOVED it! Such an amazing repository of moving vehicles and a small section dedicated to Ataturk and a nicely tucked away Maths museum for children (the bubble machine was a real hit with my girl!). They had my Ford Mustang and the Thunderbird there and I fell in love!! Oh my, my dream cars!! Do not miss this place! Well worth the visit.

Great surprise in Istanbul!. We didn't know much about Rahmi Koc museum but went there on a whim along with our visit to Miniaturk. Koc museum is fantastic! The best collection of classic cars I've ever seen in the world, along with fascinating displays of engines and other industrial equipment, plus airplanes. We paid the extra charge for the submarine tour, which was very worth it. Excellent!

Just the most wonderful museum I have been to!. This museum is a true gem, we travel there by boat up the golden horn to Haskoy pier, the collection of cars, planes, trains, boats, bikes etc... is vast and all in unbelievably good condition. There is plenty for children to interact with and heaps to keep them and adults interested and stimulated! There is also a fantastic restaurant right out by the water with great food and wine.

Fascinating place to visit. Mr Koq has the money to indulge his interests and the restoration of the buildings and the items on display are all very tasteful and must have cost a small fortune. He should be very proud of this museum.You could easily spend an entire day here if you wanted but a few hours is probably enough for most. As the info booklet states, "the first major museum in Turkey dedicated to the history of transportation, industry and communication" and it certainly lives up to the description.As others have said, it has a bit of everything and it is all in beautiful condition. We paid the extra YTL7 for the submarine tour which runs at regular times. You get a certificate at the end of the tour!It is actually quite a fun and interesting place to visit and everything is in pristine condition with staff polishing and dusting the exhibits to keep them looking that way.Husband particularly enjoyed going inside the DC3, but we both enjoyed so many of the exhibits in this inside/outside museum it is much too difficult to describe them all.When you need to rest for a short time there are a couple of cafes where you can buy snacks and drinks, and restrooms in various buildings.It was quite busy when we were there as there were several school groups visiting.We took the ferry to the Haskoy dock. It docks next to some of the outdoor exhibits but you cannot enter from here. You need to walk straight ahead through the park, turn left at the road and walk 2 or 3 minutes to reach the entrance.If you want something completely different in Istanbul give this a try. After the museum, if you continue a few minutes further on the ferry from Haskoy to Eyup and take the cable car up for the fabulous views you will have enjoyed a great day out on the Golden Horn.

Don't Miss This Gem!. The most pleasant way to arrive to this museum devoted to transportation is by the Golden Horn Ferry. I would rank this as one of my favorite museums in Istanbul and if you are traveling with kids, plan to spend the whole day. You'll see classic cars, climb up into early airliners, explore a submarine, eat on a restored ferry, peer into the insides of boats etc etc. It's history that is very easy for an American to identify with and so much fun to explore!
Amazing. This place is brilliant,if ur traveling with kids or car, plane enthusiasts do not miss it!! Our son ,9 years his dad 42 and grand dad 69 all loved it !!

Excellent Museum!. We found a short write - up on Rahmim Koc and rode the Big Bus to the museum. It is well laid out, informative, children friendly (even the stairs have children level handrails) and extensive without being boring. Entry is TL 12.50 - very reasonable. Definitely worth a visit.
You must see this museum. rahmi koç museum is the unique place. Absolutely see this museum in İstanbul. I think everyone likes this museum.

Good for the non traditional museum pieces. Koc is one the richest Turkish business tycoons. The museum has many memorabilia rarely found together in any world museum. Not to be missed. Nice building and presentation.

Doesn't break any new ground. This museum appealed to me, so I took a ferry up the Golden Horn to check it out one afternoon.A nicely laid out museum, not a busy place. Nice display of some road/air/sea transportation but certainly nothing hugely memorable. Was it worth the trip? For me, no. I have seen better before, but I found it mildly interesting and a break from the bustle of this great city.

Very interesting, not only for kids. The museum might not be as big as in Munich but also fascinating. Old trains and old model trains collection is very nice. You can sit in old trams and see what it was like. The section showing how home appliances work is very interesting. There is also a big collection of old cadillacs and motorcycles. You can also see different shops like they were in old times. A commercial plane from 50-60's is worth climbing to. It's just in front of submarine.
the best museum in turkey. the best and numerous collection can be seen as old trains , old model cars, toys , two building seperated with narrow road , both has to be visited and it takes 1 full day
Torpedoes away!. Loved going around the submarine with ex-crew member who was a brilliant guide! Lots of interesting airplanes too in this fascinating museum. A good half day out.

Sub-lime. Best way to get there is the Eyup ferry leaving from next to Galata bridge, drops you right next to museum. Great place full of big boys' toys but the highlight is the submarine. It requires a special ticket but it is worth every cent. The sub tour is conducted by a former crewman and he knows the boat from stem to stern and has plenty of interesting stories. My wife particularly loved the sub visit.The rest of the museum is full of trains, planes and automobiles, including the Harry Potter Ford Anglia and pink Cadillac.I can see why this place rates so highly on the TripAdvisor scale. Bravo, Mr Koc.

One of a kind in Istanbul!. It is not always easy to find a location with interesting things for kids, good lunch and historical sites. Rahmi Koç Museum offers it all. Lovely collection of old cars, trains and submarine. Go thee by Golden Horn boat. Do not miss to visit Miniaturk nearby.

Fascinating. What a fantastic museum - particularly if you're travelling with children/teens and you want a break from cultural sights. Very clean, loads of exhibits ranging from the type of thing you would expect in a science museum to collections of cars, trains and planes - even a submarine. There are also some good places to eat.

Excellent Museum near the Gold Horn. This is an important industrial Museum, but even the kids will enjoy this Museum. There are old vehicles suc has a tram, cars, train etc. It is just by the Golden Horn. You can also visit Miniaturk which is close and enjoy an excellent lunch or dinner in Halat Restaurant near-by. Must visit.

Best contemporary museum along the Golden Horn. If you visit or are planning to visit Istanbul and looking for a good alternative day out of Old Peninsula, you should try the Rahmi Koc Museum along the Golden Horn for an unforgettable experience, both cultural and natural attractions...You can enjoy the cafe by the water after your visit...Highly recommended for all

Great esp with kids. Great event for a rainy day in Istanbul. Make sure to also visit the playroom for children with many great logical challenges. Besides there are great historic cars trains and airplanes. Don't forget to visit the historic submarine and the planetarium.
well thought museum. it's one of those museums that wants to protect the family name so here you can see that. They have invested some considerable amount of money.

Nice alternative to cultural sights. Visitors to this museum are probably self-selected nerds, which probably explains the high ranking from relatively few reviewers! It's a fun place, essentially an oversize collection of planes, trains and automobiles, and the sub. The working train was booked out when we got there, so it's popular (and there is a tugboat ride, which looks great, for the summer). Great for kids, there's an interactive puzzle room, and lots to see. There were many brides when we visited, I don't know if there was a wedding show, or if it's simply popular for wedding photos. Take the Halic ferry from Eminou, 3rd stop I think, in Haskoy. When facing the water, the ferry leaves from the left side of the Galata bridge, across a car park, and a bit of a distance from the main Bosphorous ferry cruises. It leaves from right beside the TurYol pier (which does 1.5 hour Bosphorous cruises for 12 TL). Two hours will be plenty for most, unless you visit the sub or planetarium. Nice coffee shop (and restaurant in high season). Pretty park with kid's playground at ferry stop. Great place to calm down from the chaos of Istanbul.

Retro & Small. It seems that the Rahmi M. Koc Museum is there more to celebrate the founder than the technology. Having visited the Technical Museum in Munich, I had higher expectations, because the newest exhibits in this museum are at least 15 years old, and we are talking about technology. Even the regular car engine models are old - with carburetor and spark plugs. There are some individual exhibits like vintage cars, rail vehicles, steam machines that are valuable. Also, there are 1 or two sets which are interesting such as the olive oil mill. But the collection as a whole fails to be comprehensive and educational.

For boys who love toys. We wanted something different for our last day in Istanbul and were not disappointed. This place is great for boys who love their toys. The collection of cars and trains and boats and planes is impressive. Highly recommend this as an alternative to the usual mosque and bizarres.

different face of Istanbul. enjoyable time you can have at Rahmi M. Koç Museum. Perfect view of Golden Horn, fantastic objects at museum (visit the web site of the museum), good cafe and restraurant especially at summer night.

Nice surprise. Nice museum with loads of donations. If you have time, visit the submarine and listen to one of the men who actually worked on it. Very interesting and nice change from the usual tourist trail.

Humongous. Private museum that has everything from history of electronics to different modes of transport. Real bicycles, motorcycles, cars, trains, planes, helicopters, ships and even a submarine are on display and most of them can be interacted with.
kids attraction. My kids 12 and 8 years old enjoyed a lot the visit to this museum.it takes more than 3 hours to visit all departments

Another Taste of Istanbul. After seeing so many mosques You may want to see something different. Koc Museum was a must see. With that amazing vehicles and all the stuffs I was in my childhood again. But You need save more than few hours. Place is huge

Quite amazing. Being 'mosqued out' for the moment I fancied something different and found just that at this truly remarkable museum. Firstly, a warning - don't go here expecting to be in and out in a couple of hours as you really need a whole day to do it justice. The collections are almost extravagant in their breadth - a fabulous huge array of vintage cars, planes, boats, trains (model and life size), militaria, engines small to gigantic, Mr Köc's private collection, an Attaturk display ad infinitum and all splendidly displayed. Hordes of rather noisy schoolchildren were rather a distraction but they soon went and, after all, it is their country and history! Some nice cafés and an excellent (more pricey) restaurant on the waterfront. Oh, and of course a submarine! Well worth a visit.

very nice museum. it is museum with some collected items true history of machines and lots of details and very nice leisure area in front of the golden horn.. Take a tour and breath the golden horn in the cafe restaurant or inside of a retired ferry's deck.
Wow . It was a visit to my childhood. Great place to visit with kids, but the grown ups will also be very pleased with this museum. One of the most interesting places I have visited in my life.

We are geeks, but non-geeks will like it too.. What a great museum! We took the ferry to this museum. It's a short walk from the ferry dock. It had so much on display! There's something there for everyone. We were there with about 200 schoolchildren who were very wild, but they didn't stay very long. (As a schoolteacher, I suggest when you take your classes on a field trip, you give them specific things to look for and study, not just run wild, touching the exhibits, and screaming.) Everything was perfectly maintained and there were explanations in English. There was so much to see. The olive press was very interesting, as well as the mobile x-ray machine on a truck. There were cars we'd never heard of, like Cinderella's Coffin. The deconstructed technology items were very interesting. There were so many boats, trains, and machines; it was just a great experience.

More than museum. One of the must-see museums in Istanbul. Amazing vehicles from past to today. And very cheap compared to all the palaces.The Museum is located along the Golden Horn . The museum contains items from gramophone needles to full size ships, submarine and aircraft. You can spend a lot of time looking at the exhibits. You can see many classic cars.The cars are most interesting, I always loved old/antique cars. There are also some old shops, production ateliers, submarine and an airplane.Very highly recomend!

Not just a museum for engineer-geeks. Okay, so we are into boats and cars but this museum is a delightful way to spend time in Istanbul. It seemed to showcase Turkish pride in all things engineering but the museum told a story of so much more. There were such snapshots of world history, a Romanov horse carriage, a bomber from WWII, a Sultan's train carriage and more. We used our Istanbul travel card to get there via bus and wish we had taken the ferry, it stops right there.
Never miss that opportunity. Please just be there.. enjoy your time and every tiny/huge piece in there.. a great experience in Istanbul !!!

Might just be the best museum on the planet . We spent over 5 hours there with the kids. This is not really an Istanbul story but I have not been to anything like it and it's totally worth seeing. If you have gone to the HS, the blue mosque and the bazaars, this should be the next stop. Even if you don't have kids. Remember Richard scarrys "cars and trucks and things that go"? This it it in real life!

Industry museum with nostalgic moments. The Koc museum is a Industry Museum where you get nostalgic moments, since there a lot of cars and computer used in the 70s and 80s. For example I found my first Apple computer and the most popular washmaschines. It is located on the Golden Horn, however it's not easy to each. There is a amazing restaurant directly on the seaside, where the submarine lays. This definitely worth the visit.
don't miss. close to sultanahmet but have to take a cab. I strongly recommend, interesting and high quality place

Enjoyed by all 59 of us. Rahmi M, Koc museum was our first stop after arrival. The students in our group (50 students aged 11 - 15) loved it. There was enough to keep all of them occupied for an hour nd a half minimum.

Perhaps the best non-art museum I have ever been to.. Rahmi M. Koc is a famous Turkish industrialist bajillionaire. He basically bought a pier on the Bosphorus and built himself hangars for his collection of steam locomotives, automobiles, planes, submarines and a thousand other things he ran out of room for in his man cave. If it moves, he has one, or ten, and you will find one here. We found this place PURELY by accident. We didn't see a thing about it anywhere and had we not been looking for things to do locally (I broke my ankle the day we got to Istanbul so our four days in town turned into two weeks) we would never have found it. I dream about this museum. It's new, clean, huge, easily navigated, chock full of cool stuff and is absolutely devoid of crowds. I would have spent another entire day there if we had had a chance to get back there. Run, do not walk. PS--we don't have kids. Kids would LOVE it here.

Wonderful Museum.. Found this museum by accident, had not seen it advertised at all. All the displays were professionally presented and interesting. Everything mechanical is here, even a submarine. Easy to get to by 47 or 47e bus from the bus station next to the Galat bridge or by municipal ferry from the bottom of the lane that runs down the lh side of the bus station, only costs two lira on municipal Kart card for both methods.
A children's paradise. You will enjoy. An industrialist passion and hobby created a very entertaining venue for children if all age

Great Museum. Found this museum while looking for things to do while in Istanbul and it was well worth the visit. Beautiful collection of classic cars, boats, airplanes and much more. I think men and kids will really appreciate this visit. It was hard to find so I recommend taking a taxi which is inexpensive.

great Museum. Great museum to visit if you have a spare few hours to kill or a rainy cold day. My children aged 9 and 13 loved this!!!Its mainly a museum of transport but there are other things on show. Definetly worth a look especially if you have children and want a break form all the historical sites!

Awesome find. Well worth visiting - the Rahmi M Koc Museum was recommended to us by some Turkish friends and I'm so pleased we made the effort to take a taxi out there. Mr Koc is obviously an obsessive collector and we whiled away several happy hours perusing his incredible collection of cars, boats, motorbikes, aeroplanes, hovercraft and even a submarine!There's also a wonderful collection of ephemera which he has been given during his philanthropic works which we found fascinating, and two restaurants on site should you need to stop and rest your weary feet. Well worth a visit!

Huge place!!. I was very surprised at the size of this museum - three buildings, an outdoor section, port and railway line. You can ride the old steam train with your museum ticket.Boys and kids are sure to love it. Cars, trams, boats, all sorts of transport. Technology and experiments for kids. Mock-ups of sawmills and other workshops complete with noises and working machinery. Computers through time.Great way to spend the afternoon.Labelled in English.

Fantastic museum. This museum is a hidden wonder of Istanbul. Once you have finished the obligatory visit to the marvels of Sultanahmet and its attractions, consider a visit to this wonderful museum. It has a huge assortment of vintage cars, buses, trains, trams and planes. The assortment of cars is the best I have ever seen. The model T-ford is on view with many other vintage cars and trucks. Vintage motor cycles, bicycles, prams, boats and just about aything industrial is on show. There is also an exhibition relating to Ataturk which is worth a look. For a little extra you can visit the inside of a de-commissioned WW2 American submarine which was ultimately a part of the Turkish navy. Kids will love it. A handy hint - It is easy to spend a day there with time passing quickly. For a linch break, don't eat at the museum. Keep your museum ticket and visit the nearby Lale Lokantasi cafe/restaurant. As you exit the museum turn right and walk 20 or 30 metres. Lok to your left and there is a small street. You should be able to see the restaurant. It is clean, cheap and serves Turkish food at a very reaonable price. Once finished, go back to the museum and show your ticket, and you can re-enter. It is easy to get to. Either a bus (47E) from Eminonu or a ferry from Eminonu. For variety, go back by bus if you arrived there by ferry at first. Both take the Istanbulcarte. Enjoy this not well publicised attraction. There is no other like it.

Not Your Usual Transport Museum. Following a tip from a colleague who was based in Turkey we went here. What a wonderfully eclectic mix this collection is. Planes, trains, automobiles, a submarine, boats, motorbikes, prams and a cobra helicopter as well as an eclectic mix of memorabilia from Mr Koc as well as some Ataturk bits. Somehow, our quick visit became the whole day. The best way to get here is to take the Golden Horn ferry from Eminonu or Kadikoy to Haskoy up and back using your Istanbulkart.

Top Attraction and a real gem. Not quite the Henry Ford in Dearborn but certainly in the same league. A fantastic collection of transport, engineering, models and miniatures, Not forgetting a novel Orient Express Cafe and collection of astronomical instruments, radios and other paraphernalia opposite. Loved the DC3 and sitting aboard. Steam railway great for kids, I could spend a week there

A BIG surprise. I thought this would be a tacky rich guy's collection but I was very wrong. Koc was inspired by the Henry Fored Museum and Green field Village and I was stunned by the quality of the transportation collection. This could easily be an all-day visit to something other than a mosque or a palace! If you have kids traveling with you and they are bored, this is the place. It was filled with school groups and the kids sounded like they were having an incredible time. Nice cafe on the old ferry, looks like the restaurant was quite nice as well. Really a good time.

Excellent....for men mostly. Incredible collection of cars, train, submarine, bikes, boats etc. A "must-visit" museum in Istanbul.
There is also nice restaurant in the area with good view (probabaly a bit expensive one)

Superb. Thank you Rahmi Koc and his family. I visited photogrqph exhibition about istanbul bridges. It was great other things to see. I really enjoyed whole experience. Visit cost around 12.5 turkish lira. It is about 4 pounds or 5 dolars. It is worth it. I then visited pierre loti hill. And it was great view of golden horn.

Fabulous day out. An unbelieveable trip through history in science,travel and communications. This is unlike the traditional 'Istanbul' tourist attractions ie Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar however this was recommended to us but seemed a little out of the way and not really being sure what to expect off we trekked. We were not disappointed and have to agree with other comments on here that to really appreciated all that is on display you easily need 3 - 4 hours. Include the tour of the submarine, it is amazing to see how 84 crew lived in such small confined spaces. The staff polite and friendly, the premises were spotless (as were the loo's) and although we only stopped for drinks at the cafes they were very reasonably priced i.e. 0.75kr for a small water.

Amazing museum, adults also admitted:-). Very nice collection of trains, planes and automobiles, and etc.Beautifully set out and presented. Have a break on the Feherbahce, an old ferryboat with views on the Golden Horn.The extra ticket for the submarine is worth the extra money.

THE best museum I've been to. Our kids, 2 and 4 yr old, already love to go to this museum. There are many real boats, aeroplanes, cars, trains, fire engines,... And you can touch and go into many of them. There are buttons to push to make things work and there is a real train that you can ride in. For adults it is a place to admire so many beautiful transport machines. They are kept in excellent condition. Food and drink at the museum are available and very cheap. Car park available and free at the museum. We keep on coming back!

Not just for kids. If you like any kind of transportation, cars, boats, planes, tractors, wagons, motorcycles, etc., you will we wowed by the collection in this private museum. To know that this is the dream of one individual makes it all the more special. Every thing on display is in perfect working order--and you can touch it! You can also have a full lunch at the waterfront restaurant.

Combination of Islamic and Christian interiors. this was a unique visit for me to experience the influence religious wars have over places of worship. the area is quite nice too with some cute cafe's and souvenir shops.

Best Place if you have kids !. If you are visiting Istanbul with your kids, don't mis this place, they will really enjoy it .My kids love the history of all Transportations.and if your kids are. above 9 they can take a tour into real submarine

An outstanding museum by international standards. This a Museum which is a must for all transport enthusiasts. Located in a former shipyard in the Golden Horn near Haskoy pier, it is easily accessible by the ferry from Karakoy or Eminonu going up the Golden Horn to Eyup. The floating exhibits include the Denny-built Bosphorus ferry Fenerbahce.

One of the best museum in Istanbul. One of the must-see museums in Istanbul. Amazing vehicles from past to today. Besides all kind of cars there are also computers, mp3 players, planes, boats etc. Don't leave Istanbuyl before visiting this wonderful museum!

fantastic, one of the best transportation museums we've visited. We love transportation museums. Many vehicles are not just historic they are works of art. This museum delivers on all fronts from the informative information to the quality of the collection. You get every mode of transportation for land, water and air. They even have a submarine.We've been to transportation museums all over Europe and this is the most memorable. We even had a nice quick bite in the café which is conveniently located in one of the car rooms so you can see the cars while eating. Allow 4 hours to do it justice. 2 hours might get you a quick pass through but you'll be rushed

Little known gem .... After hours of patient shopping, museum visiting etc. treat the man in your life to a day of non stop ogling at this fascinating Transport/Industry Museum with everything from a Fighter Jet to Corgi toy collection. Good restaurant on the premises and great views across the water.

Transportation Plus. I was not too happy about spending time in this Museum as part of an Istanbul City Tour, but after the hour was up I would gladly have extended it. The concept behind it is crazy, but it works. Approaching the waterside area where it exists, the first thing you notice is the array of airplanes around the main entrance. By the water you will find a collection of interesting boats, and sheds in the courtyard display ancient steam engines, tramcars, and other railway artefacts ----- including the Sultan's personal carriage containing a dummy of the great man himself. Most of our time was, however, spent in the Langerhane building, because of the inclement weather at the time. The collection of automobiles ranging between 1930 and 1970 was fascinating, and included the 1960 Ford Anglia, the first car I ever owned. Many had their insides exposed, or reflected into view by mirrors under the floor. Explanations in Turkish and English were well done. Then there were the 2-wheel modes of transportation: bicycles, mopeds, scooters and fully-fledged motor bikes. Again, the guts and mode of operation were revealed, and they could be started at the press of a button. This theme was continued with common household appliances such as clothes washers and dryers, dish washers and many others: push a button and they start; by encasing them in transparent plastic, the moving parts were in full view during operation. As one last of many other possible examples, I will mention electronics. This series of exhibits included computers, TV and Radio equipment, CD players and Video recorders where removal of the casing revealed the secrets of how they did what you paid for them to do. Add in very clean washrooms and cafeteria facilities and you have the basis for a very enjoyable and informative half-day. But of course, it has nothing whatever to do with Turkey as such.

An unexpected joy!. There are some museums that are so beautifully concieved; laid out and presented with such imagination that the subject-matter is almost irrelevant. This is one of those.I am neither a particular enthusiast of transport, nor a person who lingers overlong in museums. However, I knew a trip to Rahmi M.Koc Museum would begin with a pleasant ferry trip on the Bosphorus and, in any case, my guidebook reviewed it so enthusiastically that I thought it worth at least a quick look. In the event, I spent four happy hours wandering the vast collection and marvelling at what can be done with a museum to capture the interest.Room after room of attractively arranged vehicles were interspersed with points of interest such as a 3D cinema, planes who's cockpit you could visit, a No.52 routemaster bus from Mill Hill to Hyde Park Corner (looking very out of place!), working machinery, trams you could walk through, videos and much more. A series of boats were moored at the side of the museum, including a WW2 American submarine, of which I was thrilled to take a brief tour.I can enthusiastically recommend this museum to any visitor. Children will love the 'hands on' elements. And if, unlike me, you are enough of a transport enthusiast to wish to study each exhibit individually, you could be here for a few days!

Interesting place to visit!. I liked the great collection of machinery in this museum. Really loved the classical car collection, it was amazing! It was great to see the full sized airplanes and the steam engines. I felt like I was into a new world of machinery! I had gone there with my family and since I have a six year old kid, it was very good to see the kids section. The boat stop just close to the museum made our travel more convenient.

My daughter loves it, so do I. It's a very well organized muzeum by the Golden Horn with lots of antique cars, trains, planes and ships. You can also visit an old submarine and a planatorium inside. My favorites are 2 Turkish sailing yacths who travelled around the world. Legendary KISMET and tiny UZAKLAR.
Good. Good educational place to visit especially if accompanied by kids they will enjoy the cars section ,informative and nice need at least 3 hours tour

INTERESTING - HALF OPEN AIR MUSEUM. This museum is at the northern shore of the historical Golden Horn of Istanbul and the vast area it covers spreads over a historical shipyard from the Ottoman period, the whole settlement lies on 3 main seperate parts of around 27.000 square kilometres, the historical buildings used now as a museum were once the anchor house and the dockyard ruins. With its open air museum part, you never feel how the time spent at this museum : there are so many things to see around; an old submarine-into which you may have a small tour, an old train trail-on which you can still travel for 5-10 minutes, an old Bosphorus ship-onboard you can have some tea and traditional Turkish simit, fishing boat-you can have a tour of Golden Horn, and so many more interesting machinery... old cars, planes, printing machines, a planetarium... This is the place for everyone : children, old and young people, students, teachers, families, parents...All can enjoy and have great time there. At the end of the day, there are many choices to rest at : cafe, restaurant, bar either on mainland or onboard of a ship.

Nice museum. We had a really good time at this museum. The trip on the ferry to get there is nice and the museum is really fun too. Our boys really liked it. Seeing the insideof an old plane, or an old submarine, all the vintage cars, theships, it is really worth a visit. When you buy tickets, you can also buy supplements for a tour on the submarine (really nice) and the planetarium (not worth it).
Much to see!. Very interesting place and very much to see. And very cheap compared to all the palaces. I very much recommend ths place. We were very nicely surprised by it.

nıce and clean unblıeveble. just vısıt there wıth the famıly before want to see thıs place before .staff werry frıendly and they wıll love to help you thats so nıce .it made us more than well come .you can see so many dıfferent thıngs ın here
Nice place to be. As a private museum this is one of the best, so modern, rich content etc. i live in istanbul and have been there 3 times. Everytime there is something new to see and explore

Kids will love it!. You must absolutely visit this museum if you are planning to stay more than 2-3 days in Istanbul. Especially kids will love it. You have the opportunity to enter and have a guided tour(unfortunately only in Turkish)inside a real submarine! Fans of old cars, motorcycles, planes, trains, boats, etc will also love it. Keep at least three hours for a visit and go there(and return) through the Golden Horn ferries from Karakoy Halic Iskelesi, or Eminonu Halic Iskelesi.

Planes, trains and automobiles. Brilliant - the private transportation collection (amongst too much else to mention), of the premier industrial family of Turkey. Maintained to perfection, and fascinating for the kids - best to get a taxi, and easy flag another when you're done.

Amazing Museum. The Rahmi Koç Museum is located along the Golden Horn . The museum contains items from gramophone needles to full size ships, submarine and aircraft. You can spend a lot of time looking at the exhibits. You can see many classic cars.I recommend to the families and technical people and interested people in this field. Please ask a map of the museum very helpful.

A good museum to visit.... The cars are most interesting, I always loved old/antique cars. There are also some old shops, production ateliers, submarine and an airplane.For the more scientific there are parts about how some machines work etc. The environment is good.

Interesting collection of modern artifacts. It is large and has an interest array or machinery and models of them from the industrial revolution. It maybe very interesting for children. I suggest to combine with a visit to the Aynalikavak Pavillion, the remaining part of a sultan's summer palace.

Not only an Industrial museum it is time machine. I like all the objects are on display.. Machines, cars, submarine, plane, and even running train,, with nice cafe, nice setting , you may spend a day , with family or without..

Was nice and nicer now. After four or five years I visited the museum again and it was bigger and better. It is one of the best museums in İstanbul. Each old car presented in the museum is a work of art. The submarine is a very interesting part of the museum. You will feel the historic atmosphere looking at the little old shops in the museum.

The best museum ever!. After having visited the rahmi m koc museum in Anakra. I couldn't wait to go to this one in Istanbul!We decided that we should go after the chora church, as the pier was right next to the museum. Walking from chora church from the pier took a long time as we just got a bit lost in the old streets of Fatih. And also, we walked past one of the pier stations by mistake, as the ferry stations look just like small disused huts! We overshot by two ferry stops but hey, it was a good walk. We arrived in Haskoy ferry station and the museum is right next to it! This museum has everything- such an interesting museum, I think it will be amazing for kids. It has cars, trains, mills, carriages, bicycles, ships, any other mechanically working objects! So nicely curated, also quiet as not many people were there at that time! They also have nice few restaurants on site, a nice posh quiet one looking over to the sea was tempting. It is slightly difficult to get to if you are staying in other places, but I definitely recommend this place to visit. ( Suppose from eminou, it will be direct ferry transfer.) You get 20% off if you have istanbul museum card.

Fun alternative choice for kids. This was a nice surprise after visiting all the usual sites with our 9-year-old child in Istanbul—cars, boats, planes, buses, and even a submarine tour. A fun break for our child and a lovely spot to have lunch for parents. The museum restaurant was pricey but very good quality and nice views. There are also cafes scattered throughout the museum, but all seem to offer the same cheese sandwiche and chips so the restaurant is a better choice. We reached the museum via the Golden Horn ferry (dock on the Eminönü side past the bus lot). While you wait for your return ferry there is also a large playground outside the ferry quay to let off steam.

Excellent place for kids 4 up to teens. Even as an adult living in Istanbul I enjoy going there. Highly recommend.. The entrance fee is less 10USD. So if you have a lot of kids different ages this is the best you can do as a useful learning time spending in Istanbul. Your photos from that trip will be exceptionally good because the museum design is 'photogenic'.

Splendid technology museum. Large technology museum with an enormous collection of different means of transportation and machinery. Very impressive. Bear in mind that you have to pay seperately for a tour of the submarine. You will need more than four hours to see everything. If you feel hungry, you can eat on the premises, or just cross the street and enjoy a very good meal in de Lale Lokantasi. You can easily get to the museum by the Halic (Golden Horn) ferry, which docks next to it.

Great if you want to travel through Turkish Republic's history.... Old cars, planes, an old ship and the most exciting one is a real "sub-marine" ... Children of any age older then 5 would enjoy it a lot. Also a great place to watch "golden horn" while drinking a cup of "Turkish tea"
eccentric gem. An eccentric collection of everything! Well worth a visit. Took the ferry to and from it, very easy to get to. Not crowded and lots to look at.

Nice Museum. Museum is located in Haliç shore, in Golden Horn. There, you can visit a submarine, a plane, or a ferry in the sea/garden . There is a classical car collection inside the museum. Besides there are different kind of collections exhibited on different times of the year, so you can check the museum web site to see what is on site. Moreover, there are workshops for the kids in the museum. There is a restaurant in museum next to the sea, which is very nice to have some time, strongly recommended.
So much stuff to see spend plenty of time there. Great for kids too. Every thing mechanical there from clock pumps steam engines to full size aeroplanes buts and even a submarine

Excellent, perfect for kids. Very well laid out, interesting variety of exhibits. The hands-on science/maths section for kids was a real hit. Handy boat stop just around the corner for travel to/from centre of Istanbul.

Best museum of Istanbul. If I decide to go somewhere for the second time in Istanbul here is definitely my choice. A very big museum about Vehicles, Ships, Boats, Bikes, Planes, Engines, Cameras, Trains, Submarines, Measuring tools and anything related to them. Must go!Fees:Main section - 12.5 TLSubmarine - 7 TLPlanetarium - 2 TLSome hints:- If you buy all tickets you will be rewarded with a free ticket for your second visit.- At least drink a cup of tea in the ship-teria.- The museum is very big! follow signs and do not miss any part. Also keep in mind that another part of the museum is on the other side of the street.- The movie in planetarium is in Turkish and without subtitle!- You must take the submarine visit and do not forget to book your visit at ticket office.- BRING YOUR CHILDREN! They will enjoy the museum more than you.
Have to Go..... When you decide to visit Istanbul.. You have add Rahmi koç Museum to your Daily plan..After here you can go to Miniaturk to see mini turkey :)

it is not just a museum.... even just for this museum u can visit istanbul.amazing museum.ı dont want to give extra info about museum.u can check it via google.i wanna say how to reach it.from eminönü and uskudar u can get there by boat easly.find the halic ferry port-pier.it is just 100 meters away from galata bridge.it is a small port.and at haskoy port u can get off for museum.-journey 15 20 mınutes.from haskoy port ıt ıs just 3 -4 mınutes by walk.

Excellent in every aspect!. This is a museum about industry, transportation and communication. Very well executed, appointed and displayed. You can see from model trains and can even ride in a real one. Model ships to a real ferry and a submarine are side by side.Ditto for the planes. Situated on the Golden Horn with a wonderful sea-side view. Includes one of the finest restaurants in Europe along with a super cafe. Very much informative and also entertaining. While in Istanbul it is a "must-see"! Nicely and effficiently managed.

If you like old cars, boats, and planes. This museum is a must for people who likes technical stuff, like old cars, trains, airplanes and ships. All cars in the museum can actually drive and you can spend a lot time looking at the exhibits.It is not situated in the areas where tourists normally go, when visiting Istanbul but you can get there by bus or taxi.

Enjoy the day with your family. This is a very well organied museum. You can vsit here for a couple of hours all a half day with your kids. You can see old cars, trains, a submarine, a plane (DC9) and you can get on a train for a small trip on the bank of Golden Horn. If you want you can visit the nice restaurant on the docks inside the museum, it is a little bit expencsive but the meat they serve there is almost perfect. They have special meat ball menu for the kids and it is also very delicious.

Wonderful View with a wonderful experince. If you want to experince a wonderful expence of a historical city of Istanbul more than 2000 years old this is one the most exiting place. You can not only have the opportunity of wonderful collection of old cars, boats and trains also just by sitting near the Golden Horn with the view of Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople, Suleymaniye Mosque and the ancient walls of Istanbul.You may also enyoy your meal delicious meal while watching rowing teams. If you want to have a sight seeing on the historical Golden Horn then you may have the chance to take a tour with a historic steam engine boat. It is also possible to experince to take a tour with a steam engine train by the Golden Horn.Comparing to many other musuems around the world the not only the enterance fee but all other facilities are very cheap.It is also very close to everywhere so you can easly reach this place and your trip to Istanbul will not be completed without visiting this place.

Worth a Whole Day. We only found this museum by accident as we saw it from a ferry ride. It is just amazing from prams to trains boats and planes they have it all. Beautifully displayed on the waterfront, plenty of restaurants and loads to keep the whole family occupied.

Fun for kids. My husband and I usually stick to art museums and cathedrals, but if you're traveling with kids, this would be great fun. There are lots of "how things work" displays, eg home appliances with the inner workings revealed. There's a great collection of old cars from all over the world, from old to fairly modern.

great space, huge collection. kind of like a turkish version of the Ford museum in Michigan. Lots of cars, boats, models of cars and boats etc. If you have kids -this would shut them up for a few hours. Great restaurant on the water as well.
if have time and if trying to entertain kids. all sorts of cars, boats, wagons, planes and a few interactive exhibits. If just adults, can probably pass unless you really into this stuff.

Amazing. Very less spoken about in Istanbul but this museum is a must watch. Vintage cars and locomotives will put u in awe! Nice place for the kids as well. They have a real submarine and u can experience a guides tour inside . It was a woe experience . Tickets costs are separate for the submarine but worth every penny

Nostalgic. This Museum located at the Golden Horn as known industrial museum is more a nostalgic museum where you see the cars, ferries even asbmarine.
very interesting to see how we changed to modern items and how we
do miss our old days.
well organized
easy to visit

Live the history. Rahmi Koc Museum is just a fantastic place. You can see hundreds of classic cars (even Harry Potters flying car), trains, planes, yatchs, phaetons and SUBMARINE! Its possible to take a little tour inside of submarine, plane, london city bus and trains. These stuff equipped with interactive parts that let you feel them they are working.

Kids will love it. This is a huge museum with lots of interactive displays for the kids - we spent an entire day with kids (3 & 4). They have a few restaurants on site. The one we ate at had a french theme. It was ok - and the prices were reasonable.

Not to be missed!. Absolutely amazing! How often can you be in a submarine and a dc 3 in the same day! Suitable for all ages too. Make sure you get your submarine ticket at the main reception when you buy your museum ticket as you will be assigned a time. I had over an hour to wait. The website has details on how to get their. Allow four hours minimum.
gabriel p. brilliant-- the best museum for lovers of transport and all types of gagets--planes trains and automobiles even a submarine

Suuuuuuuperrrr!. Although my trip to Istanbul was not so long as usually, but i planned to visit this museum.Good, my hotel was not so far from Haskoy,so i took taxi and price was only 8TL. I am not good expert at technique, but everything i saw at museum, made me excited!Especially those old cars! Woooooooow, they looks perfect!I took some pictures of them, you can see. I was falled in love of yellow Cadillac :-)))))....Also i liked expositions of old ships and old aircrafts. Sometimes i felt myself as child,i wanted to penetrate inside cockpits of all planes :-)))
Had a fun time. The museum takes a long time to go through, but I guess it's because we were all excited at everything. Had fun like little kids at the interactive areas.

Cool playground for grownups in Istanbul. It is not a spectacle, but very good value for money, spending few hours checking Mr. Koc's collection!Possibility to get in to old DC3 airplane was the highlight of the visit. Too bad it took some additional procedure to see the submarine from the inside. Anyhow, warm recomendation!

An incredible find for the historically or mechanically inclined. I'm a mechanical engineer and love technology museums, so this was an amazing place for me to visit. (My family showed interest and remarkable patience, but was ready to go before I was.) Still, there is a lot here for almost everyone - cars, trains, household items, boats, aircraft, and more - all combined with a unique look at how Turkey has progressed into the modern era over the past 100 years. Many of the exhibits allow you to actually climb into or aboard them, and all let you get far closer and touch more things than you would in a more well-known museum. There were very few people there when we went, so it was a relaxing break from an otherwise busy day.Getting there is a longish but fairly cheap taxi ride from the Eminonu tram stop. I'm not aware of a better public transit option, but the cab driver knew right where it was and dropped us right near the front entrance.If you go, I recommend taking a break midway through, getting a snack (very inexpensive) aboard the museum's restored ferry and sitting at the tables on the front deck while watching the boats on the Golden Horn.

Rahmi M Koc Muzesi roooocks!. We were not disappointed at all, oh yes and the kids had a great time - and yes it is very much a hands on museum. I have to admit even for us the big kids we could not hide our joy and pleasure of all the old memories flooding back... Where should i start ...the classic cars were very sweet looking, the train sets collections were sooo amazing, the boat collection one word - classy. The aka 'mechanics display' got the kids going and from there we could not keep up with their hanger to want to see more of what was on display. The whole place was mind blowing for both small and big kids alike. I have to also mention the museum can get very busy with local school groups and such but the place is kept very clean and I mean everywhere.
Interesting!!. Everything exposed was so interesting!!We saw old cars old bycicles, olive oil productions, and a lot of fascinating items

Very Unique Museum. This museum is somewhat the eccentric collection of one of Turkey's wealthiest businessman Rahmi Koç. There isn't a consistent theme but it is pretty cool. If you are interested in old cars, technological artifacts, scientific antiques and such, this museum is a must see. Also the location is very scenic, it is right on the historic Golden Horn(an inlet of the Bosphorus).

BRINGS BACKMEMORIES. Visiting this museum brings back a lot of memories of yester years. The museum has every thing from motor vehicles, trains, motorcycles, boats, planes, photography, model steam, electric and mechanical working models and even a wedding photo shoot. If you are into live steam models, then this is the place to go and see them. The restaurants have a variety of food and drinks, with the gift shop well appointed with gifts.

One & Only in Turkey. The most interesting museum I have ever been in Turkey, This is the only place you can see a reel and used submarine, so many old industrial items, very well organised staff, located in the Naval docks area. We saw a wonderfull Coca Cola fast food buffet, however, they dont know how to serve Hot Dog, I am not joking, a regular Hot Dog !!! They use a standary bread (pressed in toaster), it is a big shame to do that in a such wonderfull museum and a curse to that wonderfully designed Coca Cola buffet.

Interesting.. Tried to get here, but - unannounced - it was closed! A number of exhibits are easily viewed from outside the fences. Makes for a nice trip down the Golden Horn, though, through the old shipyards area of istanbul.

Great Museum for Vintage Automobiles lovers. I was impressed with a jet plane that was near to the entrance ,welcoming you to the Rahimi Koc Museum. Once you are inside the main building, you need to pay the entrance fee. Grab hold of the map of the museum. Every part of the building, they have different sections dedicated to the transportation vehicles like vintage cars,motorbikes, boats , trains and horse carriages. I love the trains section, they were just beautiful. Outside on the courtyard, there is an used airplane perched on the roof, you can climb up and get to see inside the cockpit. There is also the 1st steamer which has stopped it's operation, decked near to the submarine.Inside the steamer, there are pictures of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk. If you want to explore the submarine, you need to get your bookings earlier..it comes with a guided tour. I truly enjoyed visiting this museum with my kids and for sure that we will come back again for another exploration...:))
Try to visit if you're with the kids.. Very big and nice collection of cars and machinery.Kids will enjoy it.Trains,cars,plane and submarine,they'll sure like to be there.

Nice museum. My family liked this museum. Lots of old cars, trains , planes, etc.. Kids loved being able to get on some of the trains and a plane.
