There is a section that shows the inner workings of some machines- like a vacuum , motorbike- nice for kids who are interested in that kind of thing. My girls liked seeing old dollhouses and the furniture. We spent about 2 hours here, but could have spent more. If you have done all the tourist attractions in Istanbul and have extra time, bring your kids here. I noticed that they do a lot of school programs here and there were plenty of local kids enjoying the museum. There is a planetarium that only opens on weekends.
Great museum for kids.. Nice collection of cars and industrial machinery presented in a very professional format. It's a great place to visit if you have kids.
nice. very interesting private museum. But if you have limited time in Istanbul, then you don't have go there.

Just WOW!!!. It was a great experience to visit this museum. It is educational and interesting. What ever transportation idea you think of through history it is found there. Adults and kids really had fun. You nedd at least five hours to see the whole museum. Transportation is easy from Taksim take bus number 54HT and from eminonu take bus number 47 and hop off haskoy .

Unexpected pleasure. I am interested in all things maritime, and Istanbul is an essentially maritime city. The Naval Museum is dour, although it is in the midst of a renovation that may change that situation. The Koc Museum, however, is execellent -- a vast collection of cars, trains, planes, ships and small craft, and marine art and artifacts house in a renovated anchor foundry on the Golden Horn. It is a bit out of the way, but easily reached by the regular Golden Horn ferry. Every object or environment in the museum has been perfectly restored. The labels, in Turkish and English, are excellent. The museum restaurant is a perfect place for lunch, quiet, very good food, and right on the water. Recommended for transportation and marine enthusiasts without hesitation.
A fun museum. Big. well thought-out, not over-busy.Fun to get to by ferry or bus.Interesting historic stuff. I liked the railway carriagemade for the Sultan in the 1800's.
Mr trebor. Great place, exhibitions of a very high standard. Could spend a whole day there if you can find the time.
A must see in Istanbul. Great museum that must be seen by all ages, belongs to the no 1 industrialist family in Istanbul, we loved

should be promoted more. Very informative history musium about cars,trains,plains,ships and machines..etc vintage to modern exibits. Worth the trip which should be combined with miniturk 3-5 hours total.

Superbly different and eclectic collection. This is a museum with a BIG difference, as it represents a quite unique collection of objects, both mechanical and familiar, mixed in with art and memorabilia, all put together by one of Turkey's wealthiest Industrialists, on a scale quite beyond what ordinary mortals might imagine. Apart from the cars and the submarine, there is a superb selection of horse-drawn carriages, together with prams and children's objects. There is also a very detailed set of booths detailing many and varied facets of the Owner's sailing trip around the world.You should note this is the private collection of no ordinary citizen, but of the man who welcomed Prince Charles and Diana, the Princess of Wales, to Turkey, after their wedding. The collection includes many fascinating memorabilia, gathered from encounters with visiting Heads of State.Be sure to take a superb lunch, in the sunshine, at one of the two restaurants serving good food & wine by the side of the Golden Horn. Suitable for parents, perhaps whilst their children race radio-controled model tugboats, or go for a rowing boat ride! Visited in June 2010.

Have fun like kids!. A wonderland for people for all kind of ages. Old cars, trains, planes, a ancient submarine trip, a trip on the golden horn with an old boat... An interactive museum that is a must see for Istanbul lovers.

nice car collection, enjoyed the sub. went with my 14 year old. We liked the sub and the car collection, but the rest was less interesting, and a fair bit boring in some places. Probably better with pre-teens. Recommend the energy museum (SantralIstanbul) instead if you have limited time.

Beautiful museum with a huge car collection. There is something for every age here, antique toys, computers, cars, boats, even a real military submarine, jets, airplanes, very clean and air conditioned.
Interesting engineering items. A little off the beaten path but worth it if you are in the Halicarnassus congress area, good for kids too
A must see in Istanbul. Great museum that must be seen by all ages, belongs to the no.1 industrialist family in Turkey.
Have a nice walk in this place...You will not regret... To learn and see the real things from the past....It is really good experience....

Istanbul Transport Museum. Not everyone's cup of tea but if you like transport of all descriptions then this one is for you - two buildings across the road from each other but after seeing one building (3hours+) we gave up on the second one! Well worth the entry fee and easily reached by local bus.

Great. I visited the museum with my 9 years son, he loves it very much...what not to love about it...there are something of everything....it is extreamly nice....we went almost to everything inside....I highly recoment visiting the Planetarium while you are thereI do not recommend the Submarine, it is very small, the captine who takes you in a toure inside the submarine doesn't speak very good english so there will be things that he can't explain besides it is very and narrow inside and if you ever visited the submarine in Norfolk VA then this will be nothing compared to it. We spent 5 hours and it wasn't really enough. I highly recommend visiting the Rahmi museum

Good place to visit when the weather is not as nice!. The Rahmi Koc Museum is a privately owned industrial museum, located in Hasköy on the north shore of the Golden Horn. It was founded by the retired owner of Koc, one of the richest family dynasties in Turkey.You can see old cars, ships, airplanes and trains and there is a possibility to make a small trip on a historical train every hour. If you visit this museum on a Sunday, you can see lots of newly married couples as the museum is a favourite place to take wedding pictures.

Great for all ages. Wonderful and fits to all ages. We usually viist there with my boy at the age of 7 and always had fun. They organize special workshops for childern. While your child is having great time you can taste good food at Halat restaurant in side the museum.
Quirky. An ecentric collection. Great for kids and car and boat collectors

Great place, another aspect of Istanbul - away from the historical sights. We visited Rahmi Koc museum on our last day and it is a simply wonderful place - we spent three-four hours that day and couldn't do justice to it. Especially great are the displays explaining how appliances in our daily lives work - and being able to see too! They have real live working machines with a cross-section cut away and/or transparent bodies so we can see all the workings.The vintage cars, trams, planes, ships are great fun too, as is the train ride along the Golden Horn. The museum restaurant across the road was a fancy French style place where they actually don't charge for water! Great food and atmosphere. A must visit if you have 3-4 days in Istanbul
Wonderful location, good restaurant. The museum is well organized, especially the kids love it. Visitors go back in time with technology. Halat restaurant is one of the best in the area.

Excellent. This museum is a pleasant ferry trip up the Golden Horn. You can see trains, mint condition classic vehicles, motorcycles, a tank, a submarine, a fighter jet,model trains, cars and toys. It was a nice change from visiting mosques and other ancient sights. The area around the museum has waterfront parks where local families picnic.

Great museum for all generations. Museum worth visiting no matter how old are you. My husband and I spent about three hours there, but it was raining hardly, so we coudn't see all atractions. Don't miss the submarine, it's really interesting experience (for only additonal 7 TL per person).
Variety of things to see. Since there is quite a lot to see at the museum, I would suggest to take your time for to see all interesting goods.
Technology Museum. In this museum you can see old cars, bikes, air crafts etc. vehicles and old plants equipment.
Great place to take the kids. The preschool I work for takes our students there annually and it is always a highlight of the year. Many boats, cars, and airplanes to enjoy.

Awesome for Kids and Adults. Great collection of ecclectic items. Kids will love it and so will adults. Best place for kids on a rainy day or even not. It has nothing much to do with Turkey, but if you need a break and have kids, this is the place.

Interesting. If you are interested with art you should definitely visit this place. Rahmi Koç was one of the richest person in Turkiye, he’s mansion next to Bosporus was later tuned to a museum by his children. The surrounding and location is amazing. Each time they are new exhibits to visit, so before going there try to get information over the net.

Simply a Wonderland of Trains, Boats, Airplanes and Cars. This museum certainly wowed me with their fantastic collection of boats, trains, and early transportation vehicles to modern day automobiles. They had the little car that was in a Harry Potter film!. I loved the small wooden boats including one that came from Italy, with turquoise colored leather seats. They also had real locomotives and Trams. Especially fun was to walk along "The Living History Shops", Among them Ship Chandler where you could peek into the windows and see the various instruments that sailors used. Right next store was the watchmaker shop, filled with all sorts, of brass clocks and watches, and a mannequin so real looking that I almost started to ask him questions. The boat maker shop was filled with ropes, small motors, and various tools used to repair boats.After, I took a break to go outside and climbed up into a real DC3 airplane, DC-3. You can walk right up to see the cockpit and the instrument panel. I made a picture using my mechanical Nikon f2 in black & white film. It seemed so small compared to today's big jets, the museum worker gestured for me to sit down in one of the seats. He pressed a control switch and I could hear a recording of a live take off and landing and listen to the pilot talking to the control tower. This was a lot of fun, after there was more info on the DC3 . They said that they have a few of these planes now working in Australian for short trips. Docked along the Golden Horn you can see various fishing boats, tug boats and even a Submarine (sorry I did not go inside) There is also a lovely wooden ferry boat, where you can have tea, or coffee and sit in the original leather and wood chairs inside.Across the street, they have maritime models, and printing machines. The museum was almost closing so I had to rush thru this part unfortunately.Being a great fan of mechanical devices and machinery it was a great experience. I was sorry that I could not ride on their narrow train that goes along the Golden Horn it runs only on the weekends I was told. If you like mechanical things you will certainly love spending a day inside and outside this museum. They do have a lovely gift shop that has model cars, and airplanes. A pub, a restaurant and the cafe on the ferry boat. I think both kids and adults will have a great time.

Poor museum of a very rich man's real life toys. Rahmi Koc opened this museum of owned items probably for profit. First of all It is too expensive for this kind of museum. There is an old submarine, it is not very special but if you want to get on a submarine you can check it out. Its entrance fee is seperate from the museum entrance fee.The museum includes classical cars and some grown up toys. You would probably be bored after an hour or so.You can see the entrance fees at:http://www.rmk-museum.org.tr/english/visiting/index.html
nice place. it is a pity that we did not enter the Museum,bec when we arrive there,it is too late.however,we looked something through the gate.next time,if more chance,surely i will come there

Perfect Industiral museum with a lot of Classical Cars.. The museum is well famous with the industrial equipment from shipyards with steam machines It has also contents of great Classic car museum that you can find Bentleys , Rolls Royces , Harleys , Bugattis etc. You should have visit the submarine and the  trains and wagons form the Ottoman Times. The Museum has a Halat restaurant which is famous with its seafood.

Magnificent museum!. we were pleasantly surprised by this wonderful museum. As the Michelin Guide would say "worth the trip".Beautiful collection and very informative proposed. A must for anyone visiting IstanbulOnly a bit difficult to reach by public transport, but a taxi ride from Sirkeci train station to there was barely 16 lira.
Great place for kids!. This museum is a must for families with young children: there are many active displays for them, as well as old cars, an airplane they can go inside, and a train to ride.
museum of istanbul. istanbul is museum city. you can go to museum everwhere in istanbul and rahmi m. koc museum is really nice .

GREAT FOR KIDS DON'T MISS. If you are travelling with kids this is the place all the family will enjoy a lot. You can take the boat from Eminönu to Haliç, enjoy the boat trip, get off at Haskoy to visit the museum which is one of a kind, you can then go on to Eyup to visit the famous holly mosque there.
car museum. You can see an extensive collection of old automobiles. You can take a ferry to go to there.

Totally Amazing. This museum would be a world-class facility in any city in the world. If you enjoy looking at anything with moving parts, this is the museum for you. It is very much a hands on experience. I think I finally figured out how an internal combustion engine works thanks to the displays and explanations in the museum.My husband loves the extensive collection of old automobiles, all beautifully restored. We also enjoyed the airplane and submarine displays.This is an excellent place for children to learn interesting information in a pleasant manner. When we first visited we allowed only one-half of a day. Now we know better and plan to spend all day when we visit. Although we have been there several times, there are places we have not explored and many things we want to visit again.This is a "must do" for us when we visit Istanbul.

Unmissable Attraction in Istanbul especially if with children. We planned our holiday in Turkey but were concerned that there were no obvious places the kids (two boys) would really enjoy (not too interested in mosques) so it was a relief to read about the Rahmi Koc Museum. It was definitely not a let down - the museum is awesome, not just for kids, the amount of exhibits on display is incredible and you can easily spend the whole day and not see everything. The exhibits include an actual post WWII submarine which is worth the trip by itself but also cut-out engines, appliances, vintage cars and airplanes for the mechanically minded and exquisite models for the more aesthetically inclined. Perhaps the only down side was that some exhibits, like the tug boat were closed presumably for the season, a big advantage was the very reasonably priced items in the various charming kiosks around the museum - our favorite was the one on the ferry boat moored by the museum and exhibit in itself. If you're staying in the Old City or close by, an interesting way to get to the museum is by the ferry that leaves from close to the Galata Bridge - its a great boat ride and absolutely charming.

Surprise surprise. What a shining museum!. As we were "doing" Istanbul on our Brompton folding bicylcles, we happend to bike along. Never seen such a mindboggling collection of vintage cars and vehicles and all kinds of other technical equipment. And all so well kept and shining. A must for boys from 5 to 75!!

excellent techinical museum.. Located by the Golden Horn (bus 47 from Eminönü) this houses a broad exhibition of technical innovations. Has an excellent restaurant. You can go to Eyüp with boat from here.
Thanks to Koc Family. If you are planning to see Istanbul please put this very special museum in your agenda. All the things that you will see is unbelivable...
RECOMMENDED FOR ALL AGES IN GOOD WEATHER. great collection of cars and industrial machinery presented in a very professional format
A masive collection in a quiet setting. Wonderful collection of vehicles. Best reached by ferry from Uskadar or Eminonou. Alight at Haskoy.

Worth the effort to get here-spend all day. My husband and I (no children) spent five hours going through the two buildings and the outdoor collections. We were blown away by the scope and depth of the collection. There are several places to eat on site and also a tea parlor (if you're there as long as we were, you'll need to refuel). We could have stayed longer, but they were closing.

Worth the trip for the B24 & Levant Restaurant. We took a boat to Rahmi Koc so my husband could see the B24 bomber, which was beautifully displayed with the touching story of its resurrection from the sea. We were charmed by the variety of machinery and the obvious love Koc has for the Industrial Age and ended up appreciating the loving care with which the objects were displayed.The museum was uncrowded and finding the Levant Restaurant, where we sat on the patio overlooking the water and had a splended meal [pastas with seafood] which watching the boats was a unexpected extra.

An interesting diversion. The museum sits on the bank of the Haliç (Golden Horn) and is easily accessible by public transport, being only 10 minutes from Taksim and also from Eminonu. We visited during a public holiday and were pleased to find it pleasantly quiet. The Golden Horn has undergone a transformation over the last few years and is now a sadly overlooked part of the city that visitors really should get to.The grounds and buildings are pristine, beautifully decorated and maintained as are other Koç buildings for the public. The museum focuses on transport and technology and has a good selection of vintage cars as well as sections devoted to industrial processes and maritime, printing, the cinema etc. Nearly all the information is in both Turkish and in English and there are staff who can help.The restaurant cafe (Halat) on the water's edge has super views of Balat and the mosques and has a good choice of meals as well as sandwiches at average prices. It is licensed and stays open until 10 at night so would be a perfect place to enjoy an Istanbul sunset.There are daily boat trips along the Golden Horn, either by an old Black sea fishing boat or by a cute tugboat. Cruises leave at 10 and 5 weekdays and 10 and 8 p.m. weekends. You can also visit a submarine and the planetarium for a small extra fee. We really enjoyed the museum and the lovely atmosphere and wished we had visited a long time ago. It is well worth the 12.50TL admission.Closed on Mondays.Rahmi M. Koç Müzesi Kumbarhane Cad. No: 2 Hasköy - Sütlüce / İSTANBULhttp://www.rmk-museum.org.tr/english/select.html

A must for young children. We went to the Rahmi Koc museum as part of a 21 day tour of eastern Europe, the four hours we spent at the museum was the highlight of the whole tour for our four year old. The only disappointment was that he was not allowed on the submarine (over eights only for some reason) but they had a mock up of the control room outside which he just loved. A really well presented meseum with LOADS of buttons for your litten to press. A sure hit for any young family.

A collection of things I haven't seen before. I just want to share my impression for this so well-done museum! You can see as original antiques from Ottoman times (there is a real plane, tank, a copy of an olive-oil manufactory), also some turkish people donated their collections of porcelain figures, model cars...till examples of European culture, like UK and US REAL cars :) I took photos from my visit there, I can share!

Extremely well done museum for both kids and adults. I agree with aeronuat, this museum deserves more attention. I was looking for a place that would be enjoyable for my four year old son, but in the end I don't know who liked it more, him or me. I found myself wishing that they had something like this in my hometown, I would go all the time. The exhibits were well-presented, educational, and interesting, not dry and boring like I expected a museum like this to be. I learned quite a bit about mechanics while my son enjoyed exploring the various types of transportation and seeing how things worked (we especially liked the room that showed an olive factory). For children (or adults) who are enthralled with model trains, be aware that across the street is another part of the museum that has (among a lot of other exhibits) two model train layouts on the basement floor, my son could have spent all his time there. If you're not in the Taksim area, I might suggest taking a taxi for convenience, it was about 14 TL from the Galata Tower and took about 15-20 minutes. It was an easy bus ride back to the Eminonu area.

For the young and young at heart. This FAB museum deserves more attention than it gets. I hope the Hopon hopoff bus one day chooses to make their route pass Miniaturk and Rahmi M Koc museums.Both places are worth seeing indeed.Word on Taxidrivers in Istanbul: Avoid the taxis- their only goal is to rip you off- and even with their meters they will cheat you anyway. First of all, when trying to arrange the price for a tour, they will tell you that it is on meter- just keep a good eye on the meter while driving- they can make the price go up by pushing the buttons. WARNING: A classic is to change the 50TRY bill into a 5TRY bill and make you think you gave them the wrong note- DONT ACCEPT IT!!! You will experience this if you use the taxis. If the taxidriver insists that you fall for this scam- just tell them to take you to policestation (Touristpolice has a yellow building by St. Sofya Museum- they speak english)- always remember to take a pic of numberplate or write it down on paper- then go to police and tell them. This scam will not stop if you dont help to do so. So NEVER give drivers a 50TRY note- and dont accept this scam!!! Normal fare taksim square to museum is TRY10-15.If you go from the Taksim Square you can easily take the BUS 54HT & 36T (Hasköy direction)- departs just opposite MacD restaurant. Price is TRY1,5- you pay to the guy in booth on your left when you enter. You will not receive a ticket. The bus stops right outside the museum- you can not miss it. To make bus stop the "stop button" are just above the 2 rear doors.The museum is situated on a former shipyard- has a large collection of vintage cars, ships, u boat, airplanes which you can visit. Small train to drive in, visit replicas of old shops, collection of watches, cameras, trains, tecnical maschines.- miniature trains etc etc. When in need of a pitstop you will find small cafees all over the museum...Its a working museum and very hands on- and indeed very informative. Visit to uboat and sailing on Halic are conducted for a fee.Istanbul has so much history and historical places to see- if you need a break and want to experience something else- take to tour to Rahmi M Koc and The Miniaturk museum. And why not combine it with a visit to Eyup Sultan area, opposite side of Halic- take the teleferik to Pierre Lotti cafe for a simit and tea- and enjoy the view of the Golden Horn.Enjoy Istanbul- Istanbul Cok Güsel!

hotel and submarine from rahmi koc is superb but..... the guide[old man] from submarine very nervous. dond ask many questions about that old submarine [ww2] because that guide can make you problems [in his mind]...rest in peace.!!! but the museum is very nice and young staff is helpfull.

Hobbies Turned into a Museum. This private museum is named, owned and managed by the Turkish tycoon Rahmi Koç. On the shores of Golden Horn, it's a modern complex displaying a permanent exhibition on Turkish history of transportation, industry and communication. Planes, trains, cars, boats, submarines, bycycles, motorcycles, different types of engines, even an olive oil factory are displayed along with first industrial professions and tools. A short ride with an old train is part of the entrance fee, however, submarine tour is subject to additional payment. Inside the boat, there is also an exhibition on model boats. A part of the museum is dedicated to items collected during the world tour Rahmi Koç made couple of years ago with his boat. Indeed, majority of the artifacts displayed at the museum are from his personel collections. Therefore, it would not be wrong to state that his personal hobbies that lasted for years just led to this museum. The museum visit would be best for children and those who are interested in industrial topics. Its 4 different restaurants, 1 big terrace with a wonderful view of Golden Horn and 1 big meeting room are also available for other pruposes like business meetings, coktails and similar special events. Though the museum is quite impressive, when ranked among the other attractions in Istanbul, it can not be defined as a must. It would be interesting to visit only if all other major museums are visited and there is not much else left to do, except if the industrial history is very appealing to you.
